Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A genomic approach to understanding allopatric differentiation in tropical montane birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The formation of new species (speciation) is generally thought to begin with geographic isolation of populations. When different populations of a single species are isolated by geographic barriers, they are likely to evolve differences. If the differences accrued in isolation are substantial, these populations will be considered different species. However, the processes that control the initial stage of speciation, the differentiation of geographically isolated populations, are poorly understood. This proposal investigates the factors that control differentiation of populations in geographic isolation. In particular, it examines the roles that time spent in geographic isolation, and the degree of geographic isolation experienced through time, play in determining levels of population differentiation. This proposal uses bird species found in the cloud forest of the Andes as a model system for hypothesis testing, as many populations in this region show variable levels of differentiation across geographic barriers. Recently developed genetic techniques will be used to infer levels of genetic differentiation, and museum specimens of Andean birds will enable measurement of differentiation in plumage and morphology among populations.

Understanding the causes of different amounts of divergence from geographically isolated species will help illuminate the processes involved in the initial phase of speciation for a large portion of earth?s biodiversity. This project includes training of Peruvian scientists and mentorship of local Chicago area high school students and undergraduates in laboratory methods. This project also will involve public educational outreach on genetic and evolutionary research at the DNA Discovery Center at the Field Museum in Chicago.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tempo at which species are formed (that is, the tempo of speciation) is a major question in evolutionary biology. In this project, we employed genomic tools and museum collections to study the process of speciation, using Andean cloud forest birds as a model system. The Andes are a superb region for studying speciation. Many bird species that inhabit humid cloud forest in the Andes have populations that are isolated from one another by geographic barriers, such as dry river canyons and mountain peaks. Despite the fact that birds have wings and many species fly long distances, there are also many tropical species do not disperse very far, and therefore populations can easily become isolated from one another without opportunities for interbreeding. This isolation of populations by geographic features can lead to the formation of new species.

In this project, we tested hypotheses on the reasons why some isolated Andean bird populations evolve into new species, and other populations do not evolve differences and remain the same species. To accomplish this, we used recently developed laboratory approaches to sequences large amounts of DNA from the genomes of Andean birds. We also measured museum specimens from several different museum research collections to assess the degree of morphological (size and shape) and plumage (color) differences between populations. By analyzing the differences in DNA between populations that also differ in color pattern, we found that populations in our study system require approximately two million years in geographic isolation – that is, without interbreeding — to evolve differences in plumage coloration. In other words, if two Andean bird populations in our study system have been isolated from one another for less than two million years, they are unlikely to have substantial differences in plumage color and are therefore likely to be considered members of the same species. We also found that a very small amount of gene flow (resulting from interbreeding) will prevent populations from evolving differences in plumage. This result is significant because it highlights the long time scale over which the tremendous biodiveristy of the tropics that we observe today has been evolving.

In the course of this research, we trained undergraduate and high school students, including an intern visiting from Peru, in molecular laboratory techniques, and presented our research to the public as part of an interactive display at The Field Museum in Chicago, IL.
